title: Experiences of hospitalization for suicide ideation and suicide attempt in gender diverse adults
abstract:
Introduction: This study sought to investigate general perceptions of suiciderelated hospital-based care that Transgender/Gender Diverse (TGD) adults have experienced as well as correlates of their perceived usefulness of this care. Methods: Data were collected via a cross-sectional online survey of N = 3718 self-identified TGD individuals. Single-item self-report measures of all constructs of interest were used. Results: A total of n = 1056 participants indicated hospitalization for either a past suicide attempt (SA) or suicidal ideation (SI). Irrespective of being hospitalized for SI or SA, perceived usefulness of hospital-based care was low with 50% or more of participants rating their care as some degree of unhelpful. Older age, general trust in mental healthcare providers, and voluntary admission were related to higher perceived helpfulness of care for both SI and SA admissions. Higher pride in TGD identity was positively related to perceived helpfulness of care but only for admissions related to SAs. 
 Conclusion: Improving perceived usefulness of hospital-based care may be important for improving subsequent suicide-related help-seeking. Increasing training and provision of care that improves trust with mental healthcare providers and potentially reduces need for involuntary admission may help improve hospital-based, suicide-related care in TGD adults.

sections.title: INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
High rates of suicidal ideation (SI) and suicide attempt (SA) are reported among Transgender/Gender Diverse (TGD) individuals in the United States (U.S.). Approximately, 45%-54% of TGD adults report lifetime SI  (Grossman & D'augelli, 2007; Nuttbrock et al., 2010)  and 28%-41% report one or more lifetime SAs  (Haas et al., 2014; Nuttbrock et al., 2010) . This is in comparison with the lifetime prevalence of SI and SA in the general population (9.2% and 2.7%, respectively  (Nock et al., 2008) . As many people experiencing suicidal thoughts and behaviors (STBs) seek hospitalization or are involuntarily hospitalized, understanding patient experiences with care is important. Research in predominantly cisgender samples indicates varying levels of satisfaction or perceived helpfulness of this care  (Ward-Ciesielski & Rizvi, 2021) , but research has yet to examine these experiences in TGD adults.

In understanding perceptions of hospital-based care for STBs, the consideration of certain demographic characteristics is needed. Older adults in the general population tend to have more positive experiences with general hospital-based care than younger adults  (Crow et al., 2002; Danielsen et al., 2007) . Similarly, cisgender women  (Teunissen et al., 2016)  and people of color (POC;  Mead & Roland, 2009)  are generally less satisfied with their care than cisgender men and White individuals, respectively. Given these findings, the intersection of gender identity and other demographic factors may relate to perceptions of hospitalization experiences for STBs in TGD adults; however, these hypotheses remain untested.

In addition to demographic factors noted above, care experiences must be considered. As noted by previous research (e.g.,  Priebe et al., 2011) , one such factor is voluntary vs. involuntary admission for STBs. Two meta-analyses, one including a sample comprised of mostly involuntarily admitted patients, found that a significant number of individuals believed their admission was neither justified nor beneficial and that they were generally dissatisfied with their treatment  (Kallert et al., 2008; Katsakou & Priebe, 2006) . This is concerning as research demonstrates that negative experiences with hospital-based STB care are related to lower perceived likelihood of future help-seeking for STBs in young adults  (Jones et al., 2021) . TGD adults have demonstrated fairly high avoidance of health care broadly, in part due to poor previous healthcare experiences  (James et al., 2016) . It may be that, like in cisgender adults, involuntary hospitalization is related to lower positive experience with this care which could result in less suicide-related help-seeking in the future.

Minority stress theory  (Meyer, 2003)  provides a framework for understanding how previous negative experiences with healthcare systems experienced by TGD individuals may relate to perceptions of STB hospitalbased care. This theory states that distal stressors (i.e., objective stigmatizing events), such as being misgendered or harassed, are related to poorer mental health outcomes in part as a result of proximal stressors (i.e., the internalization of these experiences) such as fear of one's gender identity being discovered. Thus, negative objective experiences with previous healthcare systems and providers may result in negative perceptions of hospital-based care for STBs.

Broadly, those who perceive their psychiatric providers as trustworthy also perceive them to deliver better care  (Rørtveit et al., 2015) , and individuals in inpatient psychiatric care that do not trust endorse feeling as though they were "wasting their time" in treatment  (Molin et al., 2016) . Within the TGD community, research supports that individuals view providers who were educated about TGD issues as more trustworthy  (McCullough et al., 2017) . It may be that distal minority stressors experienced in health care, such as needing to educate providers, relate to negative experiences with STB-related care through feelings of reduced trustworthiness of providers and institutions. For example, as mentioned above, avoidance of health care is not uncommon among TGD individuals, as in a survey of over 20,000 TGD adults, 23% of participants reported general avoidance of health care due to fear of being mistreated based on their gender identity  (James et al., 2016) . In line with minority stress theory, this avoidance may be a result of the internalization of previous experiences, creating a fear of one's gender identity being revealed as well as potential subsequent negative consequences.

On the other hand, minority stress theory also posits specific factors may reduce the impact of negative healthcare experiences. Pride in TGD identity relates to lower rates of mental health concerns (e.g., depression, anxiety) and may offset the impact of minority stressors experienced  (Meyer, 2003; Testa et al., 2017) . Pride in one's TGD identity may render negative healthcare experiences related to one's gender as less detrimental to perceptions of care and should be considered when studying how TGD individuals hospitalized for STBs experienced their care.

sections.title: Current Study
sections.text: The current study has two main aims, (1) to understand general perceived helpfulness of hospital-based care for STBs in TGD adults and (2) to explore correlates of these perceptions. As demographics, previous healthcare experiences, and gender-related minority stressors either relate to perceived satisfaction of healthcare experiences or theoretically relate to how a TGD individual may perceive their care, correlates in these three categories were explored. Given research in the general population  (Crow et al., 2002; Danielsen et al., 2007; Mead & Roland, 2009; Teunissen et al., 2016) , it was hypothesized that those younger in age, those assigned female at birth, and POC would perceive their hospitalization experience to be less helpful than their counterparts. Due to lack of prior research, no hypotheses were made based on gender identity, binary status, sexual orientation, or veteran status. Conversely, it was hypothesized that pride in one's TGD identity and trust in providers would be positively related to perceived helpfulness of hospitalization experiences  (Meyer, 2003; Testa et al., 2017) . Finally, having to educate providers about TGD issues  (Molin et al., 2016; Rørtveit et al., 2015)  and involuntary hospitalization  (Kallert et al., 2008; Katsakou & Priebe, 2006)  was hypothesized to be related to the perception of less helpful hospitalization experiences. Due to a lack of research, no hypotheses were made for historical avoidance of mental health care or coming out to a provider due to fear of discrimination or mistreatment.

sections.title: Participants
sections.text:
This project re-analyzed the Trans Lifeline Mental Health Survey, an online, cross-sectional survey, completed between June and October 2017, of self-identified TGD adults regarding their experiences with mental health care (see  Aboussouan et al., 2019  for more information;  Carter et al., 2020; Cerel et al., 2020) . Participants were recruited through listservs, PRIDE events, and social media groups related to TGD adults. Eligibility included being 18 years of age or older, self-identifying as TGD, and living in the United States.

The final analyzed sample consisted of N = 3718 participants. The majority of the sample self-identified as assigned female sex at birth (n = 2025, 54.6%), White (n = 2898, 77.9%), sexually diverse (n = 3437, 92.8%), and viewed their gender as outside the gender binary (n = 2207, 59.7%). Participants ranged in age from 18 to 87 (M = 32.08, SD = 12.87). See Table  1  for a full summary of sample demographics.

sections.title: Hospitalization for STBs
sections.text: The following single items with a yes/no answer format were used to assess one's history of hospitalization: "Were you ever hospitalized because of an attempt to end your life?" and "Were you ever hospitalized for thinking about ending your life?" Participants who answered yes to either/both items were asked about their experience(s) with hospitalization with the following item: "How would you describe your experience in the hospital?" Participants responded on a seven-point Likert-type scale ranging from 0 (very unhelpful) to 7 (very helpful).

sections.title: Demographics
sections.text: Participants responded to questions assessing age, sex assigned at birth (i.e., male, female, or intersex), gender identity (i.e., open response qualitatively coded as feminine experience, masculine identity, non-binary, transgender unspecified, or other), binary status (i.e., yes or no regarding if individual identifies outside gender binary), sexual orientation (i.e., open-ended format and coded as either straight or sexual minority), race, and veteran status. To assess race/ethnicity, a list of 28 racial categories was included and participants could check multiple answers. For the sake of statistical power, race was dichotomized as White and person of color (POC) in line with previous research with the Trans Lifeline Mental Health Survey  (Aboussouan et al., 2019) .

sections.title: General levels of trust in mental health therapists
sections.text: Participants who endorsed a history of seeing a mental healthcare provider were asked, "Do you feel that you can trust therapist(s)?" with response options ranging from 1 (never) to 5 (always).

sections.title: TGD pride
sections.text: To assess the presence of pride in an individual's TGD identity, participants were asked the following yes or no question, "Would you say that you have pride in your transgender identity?".

sections.title: Nature of STB hospitalization
sections.text: To assess the nature of hospitalization, participants were asked, "Would you describe your hospitalizations as overall voluntary or not?" with options of, "voluntary," "voluntary but I felt coerced," or "involuntary."

sections.title: Historical need to educate mental health therapists
sections.text: To assess one's historical need to educate therapists about gender-related issues, participants were asked the following yes or no question, "Have you had to educate your therapist(s), past or current, about transgender issues?".

sections.title: Avoidance of mental healthcare institutions
sections.text: Participants indicated yes/no to a question regarding avoidance of mental health care: "Have you ever avoided a mental health institution (inpatient, outpatient, psychiatry, psychology, other)?".

sections.title: Avoidance of coming out due to fear of mistreatment
sections.text: Participants with history of behavioral health care were asked the following yes or no question, "Have you avoided coming out to your therapist(s), current or in the past, due to fear of mistreatment or discrimination)?".

sections.title: Analytical Plan
sections.text:
Data from individuals who discontinued the study prematurely were excluded. Data from active military individuals were removed to protect anonymity due to ever-evolving changes to military service rights. Data from those missing hospitalization experience data were excluded via listwise deletion. If respondents indicated hospitalization for both SI and SA, only their SA data were analyzed to eliminate possible conflation of these experiences. For example, someone hospitalized for a SA would also be hospitalized for SI in that same hospital experience and thus reference this event when answering questions about both hospitalizations. Ratings of hospitalization experience were transformed to have three categories: unhelpful category (ratings between "somewhat unhelpful" to "very unhelpful"), a neutral category (ratings of "neutral"), and a general helpful category (ratings between "somewhat helpful to very helpful"). This decision was made as very few respondents reported very helpful experiences for SI and for SA.

To determine correlates of hospitalization experiences for SI and SA, ordinal logistic regressions were run for each of the potential correlates. Model fit was represented by χ 2 and associated p-value. Both Cox & Snell R 2 and Nagelkerke R 2 values were presented as some scholars argue that the former statistic is a too conservative estimate of predicted variance while the latter is too liberal  (Smith & McKenna, 2013) . To determine the influence of the different levels of the independent variables and the outcome of hospitalization helpfulness, Exp(B), and the 95% confidence interval (CI) were reported. Finally, two ordinal logistic regression models were run to further investigate correlates of perceived helpfulness of hospitalization when all significant univariate correlates were entered in the same model to determine relative importance. One model was conducted with SI hospitalization experience as the outcome and the other used SA hospitalization experience as the outcome.

sections.title: RESULTS
sections.text:
In total, n = 7671 individuals provided informed consent to begin the study. Of those, n = 4350 completed the entire study. Participants were removed for being under 18 (n = 83), for being active military (n = 19), for identifying as intersex (n = 24), and for missing hospitalization data (n = 506). Data from intersex individuals were removed due to low representation and inability to make

meaningful comparisons. The final data set included N = 3718 individuals. Of those who had been previously hospitalized, 31.1% (n = 328) composed the group hospitalized for SI but not a SA, and 68.9% (n = 728) had been hospitalized for both SI and SA or SA only which were collapsed to form the SA hospitalization group (Table  2 ). Most participants found hospitalization for SI to be unhelpful (n = 175, 53.4%; very unhelpful: n = 75, 22,87%, mostly unhelpful: n = 70, 21.34%, somewhat unhelpful: n = 30, 9.15%), while n = 45 (13.7%) remained neutral, and n = 108 (32.9%) felt their hospitalization experience was some degree of helpful (very helpful: n = 16, 4.88%, mostly helpful: n = 35, 10.67%, somewhat helpful: n = 57, 17.38%). Similar descriptives were seen when looking at experiences of hospitalization for SA, as n = 425 (58.4%) found hospitalization to be unhelpful (very unhelpful: n = 199, 27.34%, mostly unhelpful: n = 147, 20.19%, somewhat unhelpful: n = 79, 10.85%), n = 124 (17.0%) indicated a neutral experience, and n = 179 (24.6%) found it to be some form of helpful (very helpful: n = 26, 3.57%, mostly helpful: n = 50, 6.87%, somewhat helpful: n = 103, 14.15%).

sections.title: Univariate correlates of perceived helpfulness of SI hospitalization
sections.text:
The results of the ordinal logistic regressions can be found in Tables  3  and  4 . In summary, age was the only significant demographic correlate related to perceived helpfulness ratings

of hospitalization. As age increased, hospitalization for SI was viewed as more helpful. Voluntary status of hospitalization was positively related to SI hospitalization helpfulness, indicating more helpful experiences for voluntary admissions than involuntary. However, in this model, voluntary status failed the test of parallel lines (χ 2 (2) = 6.06, p < .05), an analysis conducted to determine if the assumption of proportional odds was met. Thus, results need to be interpreted with caution. Levels of trust in therapists were positively related to SI hospitalization helpfulness. As trust increased, hospitalization for SI viewed as more helpful. Avoidance of health care had an inverse relationship with hospitalization experience, as individuals who had avoided mental health care were more likely to have had a negative hospitalization experience. Historical need to educate providers about TGD-specific issues, historical avoidance of coming out to providers due to fear of mistreatment, and TGD pride were unrelated to SI hospitalization experience (p > .05).

sections.title: Univariate correlates of perceived helpfulness of SA hospitalization
sections.text: All of the above variables (i.e., age, trust in providers, historical avoidance of mental health institutions, and voluntary status of admission) were also significantly related to perceived helpfulness of SA hospitalization, in the same directions. In addition to these variables, pride in TGD identity was significantly related to hospitalization helpfulness. This association was positive as individuals who had pride in their TGD identity were more likely to find SA hospitalization helpful compared to those who did not have TGD pride. However, this model failed the test of parallel lines (χ 2 (2) = 4.05, p < .05), therefore results need to be interpreted with caution. Further, a historical need to educate providers about TGD-specific issues and avoidance of coming out to a provider as TGD due to fear of discrimination or mistreatment were significantly related to SA hospitalization helpfulness. Both of these variables favored inverse relationships with SA hospitalization helpfulness. Individuals who had needed to educate providers were more likely to find SA hospitalization unhelpful than those who never had to educate a provider. Similarly, individuals who had avoided coming out due to fear were more likely to have unhelpful hospitalization experiences than those who had never avoided coming out to a provider.

sections.title: Multivariate correlates of perceived helpfulness of hospitalization for SI
sections.text:
The multivariate ordinal regression (

Table 5) included the significant univariate correlates of perceived helpfulness of SI hospitalization: age, level of trust in providers, historical avoidance of providers, and voluntary/involuntary status. The entire model was significant (χ 2 (8) = 53.32, p < .001), predicting between 21.1% and 24.8% of variance in SI hospitalization helpfulness. Level of trust in providers, Exp(B) = 1.705, 95% CI 1.25, 2.32], and voluntary hospitalization, Exp(B) = 4.72, 95% CI [2.13, 10.48], had positive relationships with having more helpful SI hospitalization experiences. Age and historical avoidance of mental health institutions did not remain significant (p>.05).

sections.title: Multivariate correlates of perceived helpfulness of hospitalization for SA
sections.text:
The multivariate ordinal regression (

Table 6) included the significant univariate correlates of perceived helpfulness of SA hospitalization: age, pride in TGD identity, level of trust in psychiatric providers, historical need to educate providers, historical avoidance of coming out to providers due to fear of discrimination or mistreatment, historical avoidance of providers, and voluntary/involuntary status. The entire model was significant (χ 2 (8) = 97.02, p < .001), predicting between 18.0% and 21.1% of variance in SA hospitalization helpfulness. Pride in TGD identity, Exp(B) = 1.77, 95% CI [1.08, 2.92], level of trust in psychiatric providers, Exp(B) = 1.41, 95% CI [1.16, 1.73], and voluntary hospitalization Exp(B) = 3.59, 95% CI [2.33, 5.54], maintained their positive relationships with more helpful SA hospitalization experiences. Age, a historical need to educate providers on TGD issues, avoidance of coming out due to fear, and avoidance of mental health institutions did not remain significant (p > .05).

sections.title: DISCUSSION
sections.text:
The current study is the first to investigate the perceived helpfulness of STB-related hospitalization experiences in TGD adults. Over 50% of respondents reported that their hospitalization was "very unhelpful" to "somewhat unhelpful" for both SI and SA. These figures correspond to a growing body of research in adults that demonstrates a significant amount of dissatisfaction with STB-related hospital-based care  (Kallert et al., 2008; Katsakou & Priebe, 2006) . Dissatisfaction with this care is concerning as it may relate to less formal help-seeking for STBs in the future  (Jones et al., 2021)  and broader healthcare avoidance, an already common experience for TGD adults  (James et al., 2016) .

Although correlates of perceived helpfulness of care were seen in the current study, few were related to participant demographics. For both SI and SA univariate models, age was the only significant demographic correlate, with more positive experiences being related to older age as hypothesized  (Danielsen et al., 2007) . Other demographic factors seem to have only a minor contribution to a TGD individual's experience of hospitalization for both SI and SA, suggesting that historical healthcare experiences and gender-related minority stress factors may be more salient in understanding perceptions of care. For example, healthcare

providers generally is related to lower perceptions of care received  (Rørtveit et al., 2015) . It appears that ensuring involuntary hospitalization is absolutely necessary is one way both trust in mental healthcare providers and satisfaction with STB-related hospital-based care could be increased. This speaks to the need for providers to be trained in and have the resources to provide brief interventions that increase outpatient safety  (Nuij et al., 2021) .

Results regarding the relation between participant pride in TGD identity and perceptions of STB-related hospitalbased care were mixed: higher pride in TGD identity was related to increased satisfaction of care in both the univariate and multivariate analyses related to SA admission but not in either set of analyses for SI care. One explanation is that evidence supports a distinction between individuals who think about suicide and those who attempt suicide. For example, PTSD and other anxiety disorders are more common in those with a SA history compared to those with a history of SI but no suicidal behavior  (May & Klonsky, 2016) . As this data did not control for the diagnoses of the two groups, whether this discrepancy is an artifact of any unconsidered confounding variable these differences may produce cannot be ascertained. Additionally, these data assume TGD pride was at a similar level during the hospitalization experience and at the time the survey was taken which likely is a faulty assumption as TGD identity

is not a stable or linear process  (Bockting, 2014) . Minority stress theory  (Meyer, 2003)  posits that pride in TGD identity may offset the impact distal minority stressors, such as poor healthcare experiences due to gender identity, have on mental health outcomes. The current study cannot directly test this hypothesis, but pride's relation with SA hospitalization care points to the importance of continuing this line of inquiry. This future work would benefit from directly testing gender-related minority stressors experienced during hospital-based care, a pursuit that would benefit from considering existing, validated measures of gender-related minority stress  (Testa et al., 2015) .

sections.title: Limitations
sections.text:
The current study has sample limitations that should be considered. This study only investigated hospital-based STB care in adults and thus results may not generalize to youth. Although the sample was relatively racially diverse, racial groups needed to be condensed to POC and White categories to investigate differences in helpfulness of care, precluding a nuanced investigation of racial and ethnic identity in terms of hospitalization experiences.

Additionally, this study cannot ascertain if perceived helpfulness of hospital-based care for STBs meaningfully differs between cisgender and gender diverse adults as a cisgender control group was not recruited. Methodological limitations should also be considered. Most notably, the majority of healthcare experience and minority stress correlates investigated in the current study were not specific to STB admission. Constructs such as trust in mental healthcare providers, need to educate providers about TGD-related issues, and avoidance of mental healthcare institutions was measured broadly and not specific to STB-based care or a previous STB-related admission. Future research would benefit from considering the use of existing qualitative measures of STB-related hospital-based care to not only determine specific experiences related to perceptions of care but potentially the ramifications (both positive and negative) of these experiences  (Jones et al., 2021) . How STB-related hospitalization was measured was not ideal either. Information about individuals who have historically experienced SI/SA without hospitalization is missing as no question linking the existence of SI/SA and subsequent hospitalization was available in the data set. Additionally, a single, dichotomous, measure was used to assess lifetime hospitalization for SI and SA. This prevents knowledge about where the hospitalization occurred or for how long (e.g., a four-hour assessment and discharge in an emergency room, a two weeks of care on a medical floor following a SA). Although voluntary vs. involuntary status was assessed, it is unknown whether hospitalization was based on medical necessity (e.g., a near-lethal SA) or was the result of help-seeking following STBs. Future research would benefit by connecting these data to medical records to depict characteristics of hospitalization that could influence perceived effectiveness (e.g., number of group/individual therapy sessions, medications prescribed). Further, the single item response for helpfulness precluded assessment of what was inherently helpful or not helpful about the hospitalization or whether this care reduced eventual STBs.

Finally, although the results were significant, the multivariate models explained less than 25% of the variance in perceived hospitalization experience. This suggests that there are many more factors that were not assessed in the study that relate to hospitalization experience. Treatment modalities received certainly would likely be related to satisfaction and perceived helpfulness of care which should be assessed in the future investigations. Additionally, the study lacks data on characteristics of the providers during the hospitalization, for example was the treatment team affirming of the patient's gender identity. As one survey of TGD individuals demonstrated that 90% of respondents reported that they believed that there are not enough medical providers who are properly trained to care for them  (Lambda Legal, 2010)  future research should assess the relationship between providers' attitudes toward the TGD population and how helpful TGD individuals viewed their hospitalization experience.

sections.title: CONCLUSION
sections.text: The current study demonstrates that the majority of TGD adults who have received hospital-based care for STBs found their care to be generally unhelpful. These perceptions of care were generally related to younger age, involuntary vs. voluntary admission, and general perceived trustworthiness of mental healthcare providers. This research supports a continuing body of research indicating the need for increased focus on improving the quality of care provided to SA survivors and folks admitted for suicidal thinking  (Ward-Ciesielski & Rizvi, 2021) . Efforts in this area broadly will likely benefit the experience of TGD adults, but the provision of trans-affirmative services specifically may increase perceived provider trustworthiness  (McCullough et al., 2017) . Educational resources to improve systematic hospital-based care for STBs exist and should be considered by healthcare systems  (Brodsky et al., 2018; Turner et al., 2021)  as well as training programs that individual providers can take to improve quality of trans-affirmative care such as VHA's Specialty Care Access Network-Extension of Community Healthcare Outcomes (SCAN-ECHO) program  (Shipherd et al., 2016) . Although involuntary care may be legally necessary at times, helping to maintain patient sense of autonomy, informed consent related to the treatment process, letting patients help choose their treatment modality, and providing meaningful rationale for the importance of treatment may reduce negative experiences  (Borecky et al., 2019; Britton et al., 2008) .
